captions.text:
I wasn't serious when I
came up with this idea,

but you know how these
things get out of hand.

Each of my fingers is a digit,
but instead of a ones, tens,

hundreds, thousands place,
which are the powers of 10,

Now, instead of 1's and 0's,
just use your fingers, 1, 2, 3.

This is how you count
on your hands in binary.

Write the place values
on my fingertips.

You can do it up,
or dance it down.
Put those digits on the ground.

Now, pi and binary
look something
Now let's dance us some pi.

comments.author: ozzydakilla

comments.text:
In the video she showed the first digit (of binary and of her hand) was 
worth 1 or 2^0. The second was worth 2 or 2^1, and it goes on 2^2, 2^3, 
with the exponent increasing by one each time. This is going leftwards 
through the digits. Going right, the exponent decreases by one each time 
2^2, 2^1, 2^0. The next one comes after the decimal point and it is worth 
2^-1 or 1/2. Then the one after that is 2^-2 or 1/4. But 1/2 is 0.5 which 
is bigger than .1415926... So we put a 0 in that digit place. 1/4 is .25 
and still we need 0. But the next one, 1/8 is 0.125 which is less than 
.1415926... so now we put a 1 in that digit place. Leftover there is 
.1415926... - .125 = .016926... and you can keep going like this. There are 
other faster ways to convert from fractional decimal numbers to fractional 
binary numbers, but this works too.

comments.text:
I find it interesting how things I did all the time when I was bored got 
unpraised and frowned upon when I did it, because someone did it first. 
Such as counting to 100 by adding the 1 and 99 part, 2 and 98, 3 and 97, 
and so on. Now this. I think this is awesome and fun, but all this "omg 
every kid should know about this" stuff annoys me, especially when I did it 
myself exploring my own creativity, but nobody cares, because I didn't do 
it first. Ranting about things like these gets me sent to a corner by the 
teacher. Not ranting about it lowers my self esteem to the point where 
every purely original thought seems to have been taken and nohing can be 
done that's cool by someone as insignificant as me because Vihart did it 
first.﻿

I can count to 59 048 on my fingers. 'Cause my fingers are analog, not 
digital. There's more than just up or down. I could even count to 1 048 575 
if I wanted to. And so on. Now I just need to calculate how many times 
Planck's Length fits in the amount of degrees my fingers can move, take 
that number to the ten and take one away, and THAT's how far I can 
technically count of my fingers. 


... If only my eyes were better.
